intro: Gilia densifolia var. sanctora, commonly known as the Sanctora gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its dense, hairy foliage and clusters of small, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is known for its ability to thrive in harsh, drought-prone conditions. The species is also noted for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
